abstracts.cdata!:
With the highest number of human
            immunodeficiency virus (HIV) or acquired immunodeficiency
            syndrome (AIDS) cases in the world, India faces a major
            epidemic that threatens the country's achievements in
            health and development. India's fight against HIV began
            in earnest with the start of the World bank-financed
            National AIDS Project, approved in 1992. To promote
            nationwide efforts, the project set up AIDS control offices
            in 32 states and union territories. It also helped establish
            information, education, and communication (IEC) program,
            exploiting media and traditional communications channels
            such as folk music, festivals, awareness campaigns, and
            elephant parades to highlight the risks of HIV or AIDS.
            Building on initial phases of HIV or AIDS work, India now
            faces the challenge of quickly and effectively implementing
            programs in a number of states. Focusing on high-risk groups
            and low-cost prevention efforts, the Second National AIDS
            Control Project, approved by the World Bank in June 1999, is
            helping India to carry on the fight against AIDS in India.
